Well basically you need to understand how two genotypes (NNs) are 
compared=
 so that it is determined whether they are in the same 
species or not. 
Th=
e total number of excess and disjoint genes is counted, as well as 
the ave=
rage weight difference of matching genes. These 3 values are 
then multipli=
ed by their importance factors and summed up to produce 
the distance value=
. If that distance value is less than the 
compatibility threshold, then th=
e genotypes are in the same species, 
else they are in two separate species=
.
So what you need to adjust is the importance factors and the 
compatibili=
ty threshold. 
There is no general rule on how to adjust the importance fac=
tors, but 
notice that if you set them all to 1.0, this basically means tha=
t a 
weight difference of 1.0 is as important as one excess or one 
disjoin=
t gene. (I assume that the numbers of excess/disjoint genes 
are absolute, =
they are not divided by genome size). 
You can also make the compatibility =
treshold dynamic, that is, choose 
a target number of species and alter the=
 compatibility threshold each 
generation, if there are too many species, r=
aise it, or lower it if 
there are too few.

wrote:

s.com, "petar_chervenski" 
> <petar_chervenski@> wrote:
> >
> > Check your =
speciation parameters and the importance factors for 
> > speciation. Somet=
imes there are too many species, sometimes there 
> are 
> > too few. The d=
ropoff age is important, too. The overall slow down 
> is 
> > because the =
networks grow in size and the simpler species reach 
> their 
> > dropoff a=
ge and get killed of by NEAT. This is the explanation 
why 
> > the fitness=
 drops, too. You can have an absolute elitism where 
the 
> > best species =
never get killed, no matter how old it is. It seems 
> that 
> > a fitness =
plateau is being reached and NEAT finds it difficult to 
> > optimize in a =
high-dimentional space, the smaller species already 
> > being dead and the=
 more complex are left.
> > A possible thing to try is to implement a pruni=
ng mechanism. The 
> > phased pruning techniqe by Colin Green (found in Sha=
rpNEAT) is 
the 
> > one I recommend. This will improve the speed as well a=
s the 
quality 
> > of the overall search. With phased pruning, the lower d=
imentional 
> > space is searched better. This helps finding the best start=
ing 
> point 
> > for future generations. 
> 
>

in

ese parameters? And should there be a

meters, in what manner do they 
vary 
> in different problems?

hese paremeters are chosen by experimentation, but I 
think

 be a principle to select approximate values, I mean

need different parameter settings, so how would 
a

ct the parameters?

ng, both need

t nodes

e 
fitness
